fields.definition: The user-defined name for the sample.
fields.guidance: Original ID given to the sample at the primary laboratory
fields.benefits: Linkage of sample with genomic, lab and epi data
fields.considerations_and_privacy: Can be considered Personal Health Identifiable (PHI) information. Identifier tracking and establishing chain of custody. Public facing identifier can be used as replacement when sharing (such as a hash ID)

fields.definition: The identifier assigned to the host or environment from which the specimen was derived (e.g. host subject ID, case ID, environmental site ID).
fields.guidance: Provide the identifier for the source of the sample such as the case ID or site ID.
fields.considerations_and_privacy: Can be considered Personal Health Identifiable (PHI) information. Traceability. Public facing identifier can be used as replacement when sharing (such as a hash ID)

fields.definition: The country where the sample was collected.
fields.guidance: Use an ontology such as the Gazateer (GAZ). Equivalent to ISO3166-1
fields.considerations_and_privacy: If event counts in a country are low, perturbation may be required. International Health Regulations reporting requirements

fields.definition: The state/province/region where the sample was collected.
fields.guidance: Use an ontology such as the Gazateer ontology (GAZ). Equivalent to ISO3166-2
fields.considerations_and_privacy: If event counts in a state/province/region are low, perturbation may be required

fields.definition: The name of the agency that collected the original sample.
fields.guidance: The official organization name should be used (avoid abbreviations, alternate names as much as possible).
fields.considerations_and_privacy: Care should be taken with regards to potential geographical identification associated with organizational name. Provenance. Contact for follow-up

fields.definition: The name of the agency that generated the sequence.
fields.guidance: The official organization name should be used (avoid abbreviations, alternate names as much as possible).

fields.definition: The name of the agency that submitted the sequence to a database.
fields.guidance: The official organization name should be used (avoid abbreviations, alternate names as much as possible).

fields.definition: The name of the organization with authority over how the sample and its associated information can be used.
fields.guidance: The official organization name should be used (avoid abbreviations, alternate names as much as possible).
fields.considerations_and_privacy: Care should be taken with regards to potential geographical identification associated with organizational name.

fields.definition: Date on which the sample was collected
fields.guidance: For public health analyses this should be defined to the day.
fields.considerations_and_privacy: If event counts over a specific time period are low, perturbation may be required

fields.guidance: Use an ontology such as the NCBI Taxonomy Ontology (NCBITaxon).
fields.considerations_and_privacy: Taxonomic determinations may change depending on the method (PCR, culture, WGS etc) and reference database. The “organism” field in the sample record should reflect the taxonomic designation based on sequencing. The name of the species should be provided. More granular information (e.g. serotype, sequence type, lineage) should be included in other fields.

fields.definition: The reason that the sample was collected.
fields.guidance: Use an ontology such as the Genomic Epidemiology Ontology (GenEpiO).
fields.considerations_and_privacy: May have identifiability concerns when used in conjunction with other fields (i.e. geographic and temporal information).

fields.definition: The reason that the sample was sequenced.
fields.guidance: Use an ontology such as the Genomic Epidemiology Ontology (GenEpiO).
fields.considerations_and_privacy: May have identifiability concerns when used in conjunction with other fields (i.e. geographic and temporal information).
